prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: We assume a line FWHM of 200 km/s, to obtain a peak flux density of 1.3 mJy. We aim to detect the emission at 5 sigma significance, at a velocity resolution of 200 km/s, i.e. matched to the line FWHM. Using the ALMA Sensitivity Calculator, we obtain a total integration time of 18 minutes on source. We request the most compact configuration, so as to not resolve out the CO emission. This will result in a spatial resolution of 3.6 arcsec.
Imaging: The background quasar has an expected flux density of 120 mJy. Since we expect to reach an rms noise level of 1.3mJy, this does not pose image dynamic range issues.
Correlator setup: The correlator will be set up in the FDM mode in one of the bands, with 1.875 GHz and 3840 channels, and averaging by 8, to obtain a velocity resolution of 9-11 km/s, much smaller than the expected line width. The remaining 3 bands will be set up in low-resolution TDM mode to measure any continuum emission.
Calibration: All standard calibrations are appropriate for this project

Sensitivity: We assume a line FWHM of 200 km/s, to obtain a peak flux density of 1.58 mJy. We aim to detect the emission at 5 sigma significance, at a velocity resolution of 200 km/s, i.e. matched to the line FWHM. Using the ALMA Sensitivity Calculator, we obtain a total integration time of 11 minutes on source. We request the most compact configuration, so as to not resolve out the CO emission. This will result in a spatial resolution of 2.9 arcsec.
Imaging: We have checked that the background quasars in our fields are not radio loud, so there are no image dynamic range issues.
Correlator setup: The correlator will be set up in the FDM mode in one of the bands, with 1.875 GHz and 3840 channels, and averaging by 8, to obtain a velocity resolution of 9-11 km/s, much smaller than the expected line width. The remaining 3 bands will be set up in low-resolution TDM mode to measure any continuum emission.
Calibration: All standard calibrations are appropriate for this project

This will result in a spatial resolution of 2.8 arcsec.
Imaging: We have checked that the background quasars in our fields are not radio loud, so there are no image dynamic range issues.
Correlator setup: The correlator will be set up in the FDM mode in one of the bands, with 1.875 GHz and 3840 channels, and averaging by 8, to obtain a velocity resolution of 9-11 km/s, much smaller than the expected line width. The remaining 3 bands will be set up in low-resolution TDM mode to measure any continuum emission.
Calibration: All standard calibrations are appropriate for this project

Sensitivity: We assume a line FWHM of 200 km/s, to obtain a peak flux density of 0.82 mJy. We aim to detect the emission at 5 sigma significance, at a velocity resolution of 200 km/s, i.e. matched to the line FWHM. Using the ALMA Sensitivity Calculator, we obtain total integration time of 18 minutes on source. We request the most compact configuration, so as to not resolve out the CO emission. This will result in a spatial resolution of 2.7 arcsec.
Imaging: We have checked that the background quasars in our fields are not radio loud, so there are no image dynamic range issues.
Correlator setup: The correlator will be set up in the FDM mode in one of the bands, with 1.875 GHz and 3840 channels, and averaging by 8, to obtain a velocity resolution of 9-11 km/s, much smaller than the expected line width. The remaining 3 bands will be set up in low-resolution TDM mode to measure any continuum emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Decades of research using absorption-line techniques have characterized the physical properties of neutral gas in the Universe, and established a link between absorbers and galaxies. However, efforts to identify the absorbing galaxies themselves have been stymied by insufficient sensitivity and/or spatial resolution. We propose to use the ALMA Band-3 and Band-4 receivers to search for redshifted CO(1-0) or CO(2-1) emission from four high-metallicity, damped Lyman-alpha absorbers at z<1, the best current candidates for a search for CO emission. The proposed observations will allow us to (1) obtain the first detections of molecular emission in damped systems, (2) derive the star formation efficiency in the absorbers, by comparing the SFR with the molecular gas mass, and (3) compare the gas dynamics revealed through metal-line absorption, H-alpha nebular emission and CO molecular emission. This pilot program will establish whether deep sub-mm observations may provide mass, size, and dynamical constraints for high-z galaxies detected in absorption. This would represent the first, critical step to resolving the physical connections between HI gas in absorption and modern galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
